text.p: Jazz trumpeter Adolphus "Doc" Cheatham, who played with such legends as Benny Goodman and Billie Holiday and later had a long solo career, died on Monday from a stroke. He was 91.
The jazz great died at George Washington University Hospital, a spokeswoman for the hospital said.

Cheatham recently released an album with Nicholas Payton, a 23-year-old trumpet player from New Orleans, titled "Doc Cheatham & Nicholas Payton" and he completed a three-night stand at Blues Alley in Washington on Saturday night.
On Sunday morning, he suddenly felt ill, his manager, Vernon Hammond, said, adding that during his final performance Cheatham "played very well. He was very pleased."
Cheatham failed to appear as scheduled at his weekly brunch gig at Sweet Basil in New York's Greenwich Village on Sunday, a show he had played for 17 years.

He was born outside Nashville, Tennessee, on June 13, 1905. Originally a soprano saxophonist, he became a featured trumpet player in big bands beginning in 1948. As a section player, he performed with such icons as Benny Goodman, Billie Holiday and Cab Calloway before a solo career that began when he was in his 60s.
"He had a sense of curiousity rare in someone that age," said James Browne, musical director at Sweet Basil.
Cheatham's recordings include "The Fabulous Doc Cheatham" and "The 87 Years of Doc Cheatham," released by Columbia Records in 1993 as part of a pioneers of jazz series.
